metadata.case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax v. K. Ankineedu (HUF)

facts.text: The respondent (assessee) was a Hindu Undivided Family consisting of K. Ankineedu and his two sons.

For assessment year 1949-50 (previous year ending March 31, 1949), assessee submitted return; Income-tax Officer computed total income as Rs. 2,429 below taxable limit; assessee declared not liable to pay income-tax. Original assessment made on February 10, 1950.
Subsequent to original assessment, Income-tax Officer received information that assessee earned large profits from business as procurement agent for Government which escaped assessment.

Income-tax Officer issued notice under s. 34 of Income-tax Act, 1922 on March 22, 1957 in status of individual (based on view for 1954-55 assessment that status was individual); sanction obtained from Commissioner on February 13, 1957 for individual status.
Assessee filed return on April 30, 1957 in response to first notice under s. 34, in status of Hindu Undivided Family.
Appellate Assistant Commissioner in appeal for 1954-55 held assessee's status as Hindu Undivided Family, not individual.
Income-tax Officer issued fresh notice under s. 34 on February 12, 1958 (served same day) in status of Hindu Undivided Family to assess escaped income from procurement business.
Assessee filed return on February 28, 1958 pursuant to second notice.
Assessment made under s. 34 on August 16, 1958 in status of Hindu Undivided Family, including Rs. 60,000 as escaped income.

Assessee appealed to Appellate Assistant Commissioner, contending proceedings under s. 34 invalid as notice issued after 8 years from close of previous year (not assessment year). Appellate Assistant Commissioner accepted contention, held proceedings invalid.
Income-tax Officer appealed to Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, contending limitation period reckoned from end of assessment year. Tribunal accepted, overruled Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

Assessee contended second notice invalid as return already filed pursuant to first notice. Tribunal held first return invalid, assessment based on second notice valid; remanded to Appellate Assistant Commissioner for merits.

At assessee's instance, Tribunal stated case to High Court on question: 'Whether, on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the assessment in pursuance of the notice issued under s. 34 on 12-2-1958 is a valid assessment?'
Andhra Pradesh High Court on April 14, 1964 held first notice dated March 22, 1957 not invalid, second notice illegal, assessment illegal; answered question in favour of assessee.

legal_issues.text: Whether it was competent for the Income-tax Officer to issue the second notice dated February 12, 1958 under s. 34 and continue proceedings thereon ignoring the return already filed by the assessee in pursuance of the first notice under the same section.

petitioner_arguments.text: The first notice under s. 34 was invalid as issued in wrong status of individual (not HUF); proceedings under it ultra vires; Income-tax Officer entitled to ignore return filed thereto and proceed under valid second notice in correct HUF status.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s. 34 Income-tax Act, 1922; Individual and HUF as separate units of assessment

respondent_arguments.text: Both notices under s. 34 identical in terms, addressed to assessee by name; no difference in contents; assessee filed return to first notice in HUF status; Income-tax Officer ought not to have ignored it; second notice illegal.

court_reasoning.text: First notice under s. 34 issued March 22, 1957 in status of individual with Commissioner sanction for that status; correct status HUF as held for 1954-55; individual and HUF separate assessment units; first notice illegal, ultra vires, without jurisdiction.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Proceedings under first notice invalid; return thereto not est in law; Income-tax Officer justified in ignoring it.

court_reasoning.text: Submission of return by assessee in HUF status to first notice does not validate illegal proceedings under wrong status notice.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Assessment under second notice dated February 12, 1958 valid.

holdings.text: Income-tax Officer legally justified in ignoring first notice under s. 34 and return thereto; assessment pursuant to second notice under s. 34 dated February 12, 1958 valid.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs issuance of notice for escaped assessment; limitation and validity depend on correct status (HUF vs individual); wrong status renders notice ultra vires.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside High Court judgment dated April 14, 1964, held question of law answered in affirmative (assessment valid) and against assessee.
outcome.relief_granted: Appeal allowed; High Court order reversed.

key_quotes.text: Under the scheme of the Income-tax Act the Individual and the Hindu Undivided Family are treated as separate units of assessment and if a notice under s. 34 of the Act is wrongly issued to the assessee in the status of an individual and not in the correct status of Hindu Undivided Family the notice is illegal and all proceedings taken under that notice are ultra vires and without jurisdiction.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning on invalidity of first notice due to wrong status.

key_quotes.text: the Income-tax Officer was legally justified in ignoring the first notice issued under s. 34 of the Act and the return filed by the assessee in response to that notice and consequently the assessment made by the Income-tax Officer in pursuance of the second notice issued on February 12, 1958 was a valid assessment.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Direct holding on validity of second assessment.
